personalized_feedback:
Robby — I’m really pleased with how you’ve moved from ad-hoc thinking to a clear DRIVER-style approach. You’ve shown concrete progress in grounding financial concepts (your analyses increasingly tie assumptions to cash-flow impacts), integrating finance with technology (your models link data inputs to decision levers), and following the DRIVER steps consistently—your problem definitions, identified drivers, and decision rules are becoming reliably systematic. Your explanations are getting clearer too: when you walk through a scenario, I can see the logic trail from premise to conclusion.

Next steps to push this further: treat technical implementation gaps as business-risk controls. In practice that means (a) codify and document key assumptions and failure modes for each model — a short “assumption sheet” that non-technical stakeholders can read, (b) add simple sensitivity checks to every output (what changes if growth is ±1–3 points?), and (c) run one structured peer review per model, focused on “what would make a CFO reject this?” These steps keep you from getting tripped up by edge cases and make your work boardroom-ready. For the single technical area that needs attention, pick one recurring bug or inconsistency, map its root cause, and create a repeatable fix (checklist, test, or guardrail) so it doesn’t recur.

Keep treating DRIVER as a professional habit, not a classroom exercise. Systematic thinking is one of the highest-leverage skills you can develop: it makes your analyses faster to trust, easier to scale, and far more influential in business discussions. You’re on a clear trajectory—stay curious about the “why” behind exceptions, use simple controls to manage risk, and keep translating complexity into crisp decisions. I’m excited to see where you take this next.
